citations.narrative:
On October 31, 2023, a search inspection was conducted at “Where Pigs Fly Camp” in Linn, MO. It was determined that
the facility is currently exhibiting regulated animals without a license. The facility is advertised as a petting zoo and a
camel can be clearly seen from the highway. Along with the camel, there were multiple parrots as well as other farm type
mammals and birds on exhibit. An online search of their website and social media accounts also showed guest
interactions with several regulated species as well as the exhibition of an emu, prairie dogs, a ferret, dogs, cats and
rabbits. Visitors are charged an admission fee in order to interact with the animals. The owner was previously licensed,
but her certificate was cancelled in December of 2018.
A valid license is necessary to protect the health and well-being of the animals and to comply with the Animal Welfare Act
and Regulations. The owner was provided with contact information for the local USDA inspector and with information
about applying for a USDA license.
No regulated activities may be conducted until a USDA license/registration is obtained.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.1(a)(1) 
   
Requirements and application. 
On October 31, 2023, a search inspection was conducted at “Where Pigs Fly Camp” in Linn, MO. It was determined that 
the facility is currently exhibiting regulated animals without a license. The facility is advertised as a petting zoo and a 
camel can be clearly seen from the highway. Along with the camel, there were multiple parrots as well as other farm type 
mammals and birds on exhibit. An online search of their website and social media accounts also showed guest 
interactions with several regulated species as well as the exhibition of an emu, prairie dogs, a ferret, dogs, cats and 
rabbits. Visitors are charged an admission fee in order to interact with the animals. The owner was previously licensed, 
but her certificate was cancelled in December of 2018. 
 
A valid license is necessary to protect the health and well-being of the animals and to comply with the Animal Welfare Act 
and Regulations. The owner was provided with contact information for the local USDA inspector and with information 
about applying for a USDA license. 
 
No regulated activities may be conducted until a USDA license/registration is obtained. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
